critique: This document is an executive order issued by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, invoking Section 10 of the Railway Labor Act to create a board to investigate disputes between railway carriers and their employees' labor organizations. The order aims to prevent substantial interruption of interstate commerce and essential transportation services. It mandates the board to report its findings within thirty days, during which no changes can be made to the conditions out of which the disputes arose, except by agreement. The document itself doesn't inherently lean heavily on any of the axes. It's a fairly standard intervention to prevent economic disruption. It doesn't touch on immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It has a slight impact on economic regulation and executive power, but not significantly. The lists attached are simply lists of names and do not impact the analysis.
